description: From Middle English damage, from Old French damage, from Vulgar Latin *damnƒÅticum from Classical Latin damnum. Compare modern French dommage. Displaced Middle English scath.

entries.meaning: Injury or harm; the condition or measure of something not being intact.
examples: The storm did a lot of damage to the area.
"What's the damage?" he asked the waiter.

verbs.description: damage (third-person singular simple present damages, present participle damaging, simple past and past participle damaged)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To impair the soundness, goodness, or value of; to harm or cause destruction.
examples: Be careful not to damage any of the fragile items while unpacking them.
Cold temperatures, heavy rain, falling rocks, strong winds and glacier movement can damage the equipment.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To remove a damaged or unsalable item from the sales floor for processing.
examples: Did you damage the items that the customer returned yet?
